selected.extractionSummary: Meantone temperaments are musical tuning systems that use slightly flattened fifths to produce purer major and minor thirds compared to Pythagorean tuning. Quarter-comma meantone was the dominant keyboard tuning from the early 16th to early 18th centuries, producing perfect 5:4 major thirds by tempering fifths by 1/4 of a syntonic comma. These systems create wolf intervals when confined to 12-note keyboards, but can be approximated by various equal temperament divisions like 31-TET for quarter-comma meantone.

citations.quote: rather than using perfect fifths, consisting of frequency ratios of value 3:2

claims.text: Quarter-comma meantone produces just major thirds with a 5:4 ratio

citations.quote: Four ascending fifths (as C G D A E) tempered by 1/4 comma (and then lowered by two octaves) produce a just major third (C E) (with ratio 5: 4)

claims.text: In quarter-comma meantone, the whole tone is the geometric mean of the major tone (9:8) and minor tone (10:9)

citations.quote: as a frequency ratio, it is the geometric mean of the major tone and the minor tone: √(10/9 × 9/8) = √(5/4) = 1.1180340

claims.text: 12-tone equal temperament narrows perfect fifths by about 2 cents or 1/12 of a Pythagorean comma

citations.quote: it narrows the perfect fifths by about 2 cents or 1/12 of a Pythagorean comma to give a frequency ratio of 2^(7/12):1

citations.quote: It was commonly used from the early 16th century till the early 18th, after which twelve-tone equal temperament eventually came into general use

citations.quote: Quarter-comma meantone can be well approximated by a division of the octave into 31 equal steps

citations.quote: there is a residual gap in quarter-comma meantone tuning between the last of the upper sequence of six fifths and the last of the lower sequence; e.g. between F♯ and G♭ if the starting point is chosen as C, which, adjusted for the octave, are in the ratio of 125/128 or −41.06 cents

claims.text: Third-comma meantone produces just minor thirds with a 6:5 ratio

citations.quote: three descending fifths (such as A D G C) produce a just minor third (A C) of ratio 6/5

selected.extractionSummary: Equal temperament is a tuning system that divides the octave into equal steps, with 12-tone equal temperament (12 TET) being the dominant Western system since the 18th century. The mathematical foundation involves dividing the octave by the 12th root of 2 (≈1.059463), creating semitones of 100 cents each. While 12 TET approximates just intervals reasonably well, it introduces small tuning errors, with thirds being the most affected intervals.

citations.quote: In classical music and Western music in general, the most common tuning system since the 18th century has been 12 equal temperament

claims.text: In 12 TET, the frequency ratio between adjacent semitones is the 12th root of 2, approximately 1.059463

citations.quote: with a ratio equal to the 12th root of 2, ≈ 1.05946

citations.quote: The two figures frequently credited with the achievement of exact calculation of equal temperament are Zhu Zaiyu (also romanized as Chu-Tsaiyu. Chinese: 朱載堉) in 1584 and Simon Stevin in 1585

selected.extractionSummary: This is a comprehensive scientific examination of music theory, covering the physics of sound production in musical instruments, various tuning systems (just intonation, equal temperament, Pythagorean), and psychoacoustic principles of human sound perception. The work systematically explains how vibrating strings produce overtones, how different tuning systems create frequency ratios between musical notes, and how instruments generate sound through various physical mechanisms. It bridges the gap between the mathematical/physical foundations of music and the artistic experience.

claims.text: A vibrating string with fixed ends can only vibrate at certain frequencies determined by the wave equation, producing a fundamental frequency and overtones at integer multiples

citations.label: string_physics
citations.quote: Governed by physical laws, the string under tension with two ends fixed can only vibrate at certain frequencies. The mathematical equation describing a (small-amplitude) vibrating string (with viscous damping being neglected) is actually in a form of the so-called (one-dimensional) 'wave equation'

citations.label: sound_speed

citations.label: frequency_dependent_decay
citations.quote: It can be theoretically shown that the sound intensity decreases with the traversed distance x according to a law exp(−2γx) with the 'absorption coefficient' γ ∝ ω². Hence, the high frequency components of sound decays much faster with propagation distance than the low frequency components.

selected.extractionSummary: Kyle Gann explains just intonation tuning, where pitches are defined as frequency ratios (like 3/2 for a perfect fifth) rather than equal temperament's 12 equal divisions. He argues that equal temperament, while allowing easy transposition, creates buzzy, less pure intervals compared to the mathematically simple ratios of just intonation. The article provides detailed examples of various tuning systems and claims that just intonation creates more meditative, introspective music while equal temperament promotes nervous energy and action.

claims.text: A 2-to-1 frequency ratio creates an octave interval

citations.quote: if one pitch vibrates at 200 cycles per second, and another pitch vibrates at 400 cycles per second, then the two pitches make an octave, the most basic of musical intervals

claims.text: A 3/2 frequency ratio produces a perfect fifth interval

citations.quote: If one pitch vibrates at 200 cycles per second and another at 300 cycles per second, we have a 3/2 ratio. This is what musicians commonly call a "perfect fifth": C to G

claims.text: A 5/4 frequency ratio produces a major third interval

citations.quote: The fraction or ratio 5/4 gives us what musicians call a "major third," that is, E in the key of C

claims.text: Ptolemy's major scale from the 2nd century AD used specific frequency ratios

citations.quote: Ever since Ptolemy in the second century A.D., our major scale has been an approximation of the following ratios: C D E F G A B C 1/1 9/8 5/4 4/3 3/2 5/3 15/8 2/1

claims.text: The human ear can calculate exact frequency ratios with astonishing accuracy

citations.quote: your voice and ear are unconsciously measuring these ratios to the tonic pitch... Didn't know your ear could calculate exact ratios between frequencies, did you? It can, with astonishing accuracy

claims.text: Equal temperament creates audible beating between sustained pitches

citations.quote: We divide the octave into 12 equal intervals not because it sound better that way - it doesn't at all, it's slightly buzzy with audible beating between sustained pitches

claims.text: Equal temperament tuning is responsible for cultural psychology favoring progress and action over introspection

citations.quote: Ben Johnston, was convinced that our tuning is responsible for much of our cultural psychology, the fact that we are so geared toward progress and action and violence and so little attuned to introspection, contentment, and acquiesence

claims.text: Just intonation makes music sound more meditative while equal temperament creates nervous energy

citations.quote: Equal temperament could be described as the musical equivalent to eating a lot of red meat and processed sugars and watching violent action films. The music doesn't turn your attention inward, it makes you want to go out and work off your nervous energy on something

claims.text: In just intonation, to add intervals you multiply their ratios

citations.quote: to add two intervals together, you have to multiply their ratios. For example, a major third (5/4) plus a minor third (6/5) equals 5/4 x 6/5 = 6/4 = 3/2, which is a perfect fifth

openQuestions: Can the claimed psychological effects of different tuning systems be scientifically measured?

selected.sourceTitle: Distorted Sounds: Unlocking the Physics of Modern Music
selected.extractionSummary: This academic paper explores the physics behind modern music, particularly focusing on how guitar amplifier distortion creates new musical notes not played by the musician. The authors examine the harmonic series, tuning systems, and why equal temperament tuning is mathematically imperfect but practically necessary. They demonstrate how nonlinear amplification generates additional frequencies through trigonometric principles and explain why some distorted chords create the perception of low notes that aren't actually present.

claims.text: When a musical note is played on an instrument, it vibrates not just at the fundamental frequency but also at integer multiples of that frequency (harmonics), producing overtones at 2x, 3x, 4x the fundamental frequency

citations.label: harmonic_series_definition
citations.quote: When we play an A3 on an instrument, material inside the instrument vibrates not just at 220 Hz, but also at integer multiples of that fundamental frequency, producing sound at 440 Hz, 660 Hz, 880 Hz, and so on.

claims.text: Consonant chords are composed of notes with the most overlap between their overtone series

citations.label: consonance_theory
citations.quote: consonant chords are composed of notes with the most overlap between their overtone series

claims.text: Equal temperament tuning is mathematically always out of tune because it uses irrational frequency ratios instead of the rational ratios found in natural harmonics

citations.label: equal_temperament_flaw
citations.quote: This is an irrational number and thus differs from the rational frequency intervals of harmonic tuning. In other words, Equal temperament is always out of tune.

claims.text: Distorted guitar amplifiers create new musical notes that are not played by the musician through nonlinear amplification

citations.label: distortion_creates_notes
citations.quote: we derive and illustrate how a distorted amplifier creates new musical notes that are not played by the musician, greatly simplifying the playing technique

claims.text: The 12-note Western musical scale is mathematically derived from the perfect fifth interval (3:2 frequency ratio) through Pythagorean tuning

citations.label: twelve_note_origin
citations.quote: The scale is derived by choosing a frequency for the first note of the scale called the tonic. All other notes are derived by either moving up by a fifth by multiplying the frequency by 3/2, or down by multiplying the frequency by 2/3
